pathway: Pharmacy First – Otitis Media with Effusion (Glue Ear) – children and young people
notes: Glue ear is usually self-limiting; 50% resolve within 3 months. Focus on watchful waiting, hearing surveillance and speech development.
Exclude acute otitis media, cholesteatoma, or sensorineural hearing loss before labelling glue ear.
Children with Down's syndrome, cleft palate or craniofacial syndromes warrant early ENT review regardless of duration.
Discuss auto-inflation devices (Otovent®) for children ≥3 years who can cooperate, alongside allergy management if indicated.

decisionTree.title: Presentation
decisionTree.question: Are symptoms consistent with glue ear (otitis media with effusion)?

suggestive: Fluctuating conductive hearing loss or inattentiveness
Aural fullness, popping, imbalance without acute pain
Flat tympanogram or visible fluid level behind intact tympanic membrane if otoscope/tympanometer available
exclude: Fever, acute otalgia or bulging TM (consider acute otitis media)
Recurrent foul-smelling otorrhoea (consider chronic suppurative otitis media)

yes.title: Urgent considerations
yes.question: Does the child meet ANY urgent referral criteria?

emergency: Acute mastoiditis signs: post-auricular swelling, protruding pinna, severe systemic illness
Facial nerve weakness, vertigo or meningitis symptoms
sameDay: Immunocompromised or cochlear implant recipients with suspected middle-ear effusion

yes.title: Emergency/same-day referral
actions: Escalate via GP, ENT on-call or A&E depending on severity (consider NEWS2).
Do not initiate decongestants or antibiotics; prioritise timely review.

no.title: High-risk groups
no.question: Is the patient in a high-risk group for persistent glue ear?
details: Down's syndrome, cleft palate or craniofacial abnormality
Permanent childhood hearing impairment or speech/language delay
Significant learning difficulty or developmental regression

yes.title: Expedite ENT/audiology
actions: Arrange ENT or paediatric audiology referral within 6 weeks.
Share written advice on communication tactics (face the child, reduce background noise) while awaiting assessment.

next.title: Watchful waiting and conservative management
actions: Educate carers that most cases resolve within 3 months; avoid routine antibiotics, antihistamines or decongestants.
Recommend auto-inflation (Otovent®) twice daily if child can cooperate and there is no acute infection.
Address contributory allergic rhinitis with saline sprays or GP-prescribed intranasal steroids.
Arrange follow-up in ~6 weeks to review hearing concerns.

next.title: Assess functional impact
next.question: Is there documented hearing loss ≥ 25 dB in best ear OR speech, language or educational concerns?
details: Use school reports, parental observations, or prior audiograms if available.
Consider unilateral cases with significant listening difficulties.

yes.title: Refer for audiology/ENT
actions: Arrange formal audiometry and ENT review (possible grommets ± adenoidectomy) within 6–12 weeks.
Document the duration of effusion and impact on daily life.

no.title: Enhanced self-management
actions: Continue watchful waiting up to 6 months total with regular monitoring.
Provide school-based listening tactics (sitting near teacher, preferential seating).
Offer written resources for parents on speech and language stimulation.
Reassess sooner if new symptoms develop (pain, fever, otorrhoea).

no.title: Reconsider diagnosis
actions: If there is acute pain or fever, switch to the acute otitis media pathway.
Persistent offensive discharge suggests chronic suppurative otitis media; use that workflow.
Consider temporomandibular dysfunction, eustachian tube dysfunction without effusion, or behavioural causes of inattention.
